term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.
To record details of a laboratory specimen.
Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.
Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.
Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.
The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy, resection.
Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken.

e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.
The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
Dimensions / weight / quantity of sample or other physical details of a bodily fluid. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles.
The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy.
The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.
Is the specimen adequate for testing?
Specific issue with a received specimen.
Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.
An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.
An error arose when handling the specimen.
The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.
An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.
The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.
The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.
The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.
The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Addtional details related to specific collection methods e.g. needle biopsy.
To record the phycial properties of an object.
Narrative description of the physical properties of the object.
Digital image, video or diagram representing the findings.
The width or breadth of the object from side to side.
The vertical height or depth of the object.
The three dimensional volume of the object.
The two dimensional area of the object.
To record the phycial properties of an object.
Narrative description of the physical properties of the object.
Digital image, video or diagram representing the findings.
The width or breadth of the object from side to side.
The vertical height or depth of the object.
The three dimensional volume of the object.
The two dimensional area of the object.
To record findings of tumour metastases in lymph nodes.
Number of nodes which show tumour involvement.
Extent of tumour expressed as a maximum length. Applies only to an individual node.
The anatomical location of the lymph node or site being reported.
Nature or grade of the tumour, if present.
The tumour is of a focal nature.
The tumour is of a diffuse nature.
Extent of extranodal tumour expressed as a maximum length.
The node is completely invaded by tumour.
Findings of lymph node involvement with tumour.
Tumour is present in left sided nodes only.
Tumour is present in right side nodes only.
Tumour is present in nodes on both sides.
Tumour is absent from the lymph node site.
Lymph node involvement by tumour is equivocal.
Llymph node involvement by tumour has not been determined.
The nature of tumour has not been determnined.
Findings of extension of tumour beyond a node capsule.
Extra-capsular involvement by tumour is present.
Extra-capsular involvement by tumour is absent.
Extra-capsular involvement by tumour is equivocal.
Extra-capsular involvement by tumour has not been determined.
Findings related to extension of tumour external to the nodal capsule.
A text description of lymph node involvement by tumour.
The name for the lymph node site being reported. May be a general location e.g. 'Axillary nodes', a relative site e.g. 'Sentinel nodes' or a individual node.
Lymph node involvement with tumour is present.
Has the appropriate lymph node tissue been made available for examination?
Further details of lymph node metastasis at this site e.g individual nodes or further levels
The route by which the tumour became involved in lymph node tissue.
The tumour involved the lymph node by direct spread.
The tumour involved the lymph node by metastasis.
Findings of whether marker dye has been taken up by the lymph node or lymph node group.
Radioactivity count measured after use of radiocolloid.
To record the phycial properties of an object.
Narrative description of the physical properties of the object.
Digital image, video or diagram representing the findings.
The width or breadth of the object from side to side.
The vertical height or depth of the object.
The three dimensional volume of the object.
The two dimensional area of the object.

item.list: Extent to other organs or tissues

term_definitions.items: Details of tumour involvement at margins of surgical resections/biopsies.
Evidence of tumour at a surgical resection margin.
Details where tumour is present at the surgical resection margin.
When tumour is present at surgical resection margin, the maximal length of involvement.
Details where tumour is absent from surgical resection margins.
When tumour is absent, the distance from tumour to the closest surgical resection margin.
A text description of tumour involvement at the surgical resection margin.
Ttumour is present at the surgical resection margin.
Tumour is absent from the surgical resection margin.
Presence of tumour at surgical resection margins has not been determined.
Presence of tumour at the surgical resection margin is equivocal.
The name of the margin being described e.g. Deep margin, Vascular margin, Bronchial margin.
The location of the margin being described.
The nature of involvement of the tumour with the surgical margin.
Details of tumour involvement at margins of surgical resections/biopsies.
Evidence of tumour at a surgical resection margin.
Details where tumour is present at the surgical resection margin.
When tumour is present at surgical resection margin, the maximal length of involvement.
Details where tumour is absent from surgical resection margins.
When tumour is absent, the distance from tumour to the closest surgical resection margin.
A text description of tumour involvement at the surgical resection margin.
Ttumour is present at the surgical resection margin.
Tumour is absent from the surgical resection margin.
Presence of tumour at surgical resection margins has not been determined.
Presence of tumour at the surgical resection margin is equivocal.
The name of the margin being described e.g. Deep margin, Vascular margin, Bronchial margin.
The location of the margin being described.
The nature of involvement of the tumour with the surgical margin.

Stage I is carcinoma strictly confined to the cervix; extension to the uterine corpus should be disregarded. The diagnosis of both Stages IA1 and IA2 should be based on microscopic examination of removed tissue, preferably a cone, which must include the entire lesion.
Invasive cancer identified only microscopically. Invasion is limited to measured stromal invasion with a maximum depth of 5 mm and no wider than 7 mm.
Measured invasion of the stroma no greater than 3 mm in depth and no wider than 7 mm diameter.
Measured invasion of stroma greater than 3 mm but no greater than 5 mm in depth and no wider than 7 mm in diameter.
Clinical lesions confined to the cervix or preclinical lesions greater than Stage IA. All gross lesions even with superficial invasion are Stage IB cancers.
Clinical lesions no greater than 4 cm in size.
Clinical lesions greater than 4 cm in size.
Stage II is carcinoma that extends beyond the cervix, but does not extend into the pelvic wall. The carcinoma involves the vagina, but not as far as the lower third.
No obvious parametrial involvement. Involvement of up to the upper two-thirds of the vagina.
Obvious parametrial involvement, but not into the pelvic sidewall.

Stage III is carcinoma that has extended into the pelvic sidewall. On rectal examination, there is no cancer-free space between the tumour and the pelvic sidewall. The tumour involves the lower third of the vagina. All cases with hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney are Stage III cancers.
No extension into the pelvic sidewall but involvement of the lower third of the vagina.
Extension into the pelvic sidewall or hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney.
Stage IV is carcinoma that has extended beyond the true pelvis or has clinically involved the mucosa of the bladder and/or rectum.
Spread of the tumour into adjacent pelvic organs.
A framework for the classification and grading of malignancies using the TNM classification system.
Clinical TNM pre-treatment classification based on physical examination, imaging and biopsies.
Clincal assessment of the primary tumour.
Clinical assessment of the regional lymph nodes.
Pathological staging. Based on the clinical staging, results of procedures and pathological/histo-pathological assessment.
Pathological assessment of the primary tumour.
Pathological assessment of the regional lymph nodes.
The overall Clinical staging derived from each T, N and M component e.g T1aM0NX. May include additional TNM descriptors.
The overall Pathological staging derived from each pT, pN and pM component. May include additional TNM descriptors.
A text comment on the Clinical staging.
A text comment on the Pathological staging.
Clinical assessment of post-treatment residual tumour.
Presence of residual tumour cannot be assessed.
Pathological assessment of post-treatment residual tumour.
Presence of residual tumour cannot be assessed.
Grade of differentiation cannot be assessed.
Squamous cell carcinoma NOS (not otherwise specified)
Low-grade neuroendocrine tumour - atypical carcinoid tumour
invasive tumour in more than 3 blocks
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) / cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 1 (CIN 1)
High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) / cervical intraepithelial lesion grade 2 (CIN 2)
High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) / cervical intraepithelial lesion grade 3 (CIN 3)
Suspicious for squamous intraepithelial lesion (PIL) / cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
Extent to other organs or tissues
Details about an multimedia representation of the clinical data.
Multimedia representation of the clinical observation or finding.
Title or identification of the multimedia resource.
The source of the multimedia resource.
Date/time that the multimedia resource was created.
Narrative description of the multimedia resource.
Date/time that the multimedia resource was published.
The version of the multimedia resource.
Internet link to the multimedia resource.
Name of the creator of the resource.
A physical site on or within the human body.
Identification of a single physical site either on, or within, the human body.

This data element is the only mandated data point in this archetype and should be used as the primary data point to record an anatomical location with a commonly used name. It is strongly recommended that 'Body site name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. Use the other data elements for laterality, aspect, region and anatomical line to provide more detail.
This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available.
If body site name is already identified in the parent archetype, then this data element may be redundant. Alternatively, a use case has been identified where the value may be duplicated into this element to support semantic querying using this archetype, rather than the data element within the parent.
The side of the body on which the identified body site is located.

If the identified body site has no laterality, this data element should not have a value. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include laterality, then this data element is redundant.
Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support the 'Body site name'.
For example: adjacent to the vermilion border; a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.
Additional detail about the anatomical site using alternative approaches to describe the same body site.
For example, relative location or precise locations using coordinates.
Image or other media used to support identification of the body site.
Additional detail using theoretical lines drawn through anatomical structures used to provide a consistent reference point on the human body.

Common anatomical lines have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. The additional use of this data element allows for recording of the typical position of the heart's apex beat at 5th intercostal space, left side, and mid-clavicular line. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include anatomical line, then this data element is redundant.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the apex of the axilla.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the anterior axillary skinfold.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the posterior axillary skinfold.
Line running vertically down the surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the midpoint of the clavicle.
Line running vertically down the face through the midpoint of the pupil when looking directly forward.

Line running vertically which divides the body into left and right portions, passing through the head, spinal cord, and umbilicus. Alternatively it can refer to a line dividing a body part into two equal portions, for example a digit.
Line running vertically down the posterior surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the inferior point of the scapula.
Qualifying detail about the specific aspect of the identified body site.

Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. For example: proximal urethra; plantar aspect of the left thumb. Multiple aspects can also be described, if required, by allowing for 0..2 occurrences. For example: a lesion may be on the left anterior/lateral (ie anterolateral) chest wall. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the aspect, then this data element is redundant.
Additional detail using a specific region or a point on, or within, the identified body site.

Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. For example, the upper right quadrant or McBurney's point on the abdominal wall or interphalangeal joint of the great toe. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the specific site, then this data element is redundant.
Towards the midline of the body site.
Towards the side, or edge, of the body site.
Above the body site, often meaning towards the head.
Below the body site, often meaning towards the feet.
Towards the front, or ventral surface, of the body site.
Towards the back, or dorsal surface, of the body site.
More central or closer to the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.
More peripheral, or further from the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.
Towards the palm of the hand.
Towards the sole of the foot.
In the middle of the body site.
Towards the mouth. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.
Towards the anus. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.
Away from the surface of the body site.
Towards the surface of the body site.
Towards the back of the hand or top of the foot. To be used as opposites of palmar or plantar, not as a synonym of posterior.
Details of a specimen container. This is often integral to workflow and reporting of pathology specimens, particularly anatomical and histological pathology specimens.
Identifier of the place from where the container should be collected.
The unique identifier given to the container. May be multiple.
The container is a tissue cassette.
The container is a tissue microarray cassette.
The container is a specimen vial.
The container is a microscope slide.
The container is a gneric specimen container.
The container is an electron microscopy grid.
The container is a specimen well.
A text description of the container.
The data and time that the specimen was uplifted for transportation to the laboratory.
Identifier of person or agency responsible for transporting the container to the lab.
Any special fixative or transport medium requirements.
Details of a sub-components which comprises the container (e.g. description of the slide and of the coverslip).
To record details of a laboratory specimen.
Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.
Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.
Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.
The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy, resection.
Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken.

e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.
The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
Dimensions / weight / quantity of sample or other physical details of a bodily fluid. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles.
The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy.
Date and time of receiving the specimen
The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.
Is the specimen adequate for testing?
Specific issue with a received specimen.
Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.
An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.
An error arose when handling the specimen.
The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.
An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.
The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.
The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.
The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.
The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Addtional details related to specific collection methods e.g. needle biopsy.
Findings and interpretation of histopathology (anatomic pathology) tests performed on tissues and body fluids.
Findings related to tissue examined intra-operatively.
Findings recorded on examination of a gross specimen.
Details of an individual histopathology finding, often related to a specific anatomical location or specimen.
True if the tissue is available for examination.
Details of specimen(s) related to this examination.
A narrative description of the histopathology finding.
Single word, phrase of brief description representing the interpretation of the histopathology finding. A coded term is preferred.
A narrative description of the group of histopathology findings.
A group of findings within the histopathology examination. The Runtime name constraint allows identification of the type of histopathology examination performed.
Rich text or other multimedia representation of this particular result as issued by the diagnostic service.
Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Name in free text unstructured format.
Name previously used by this person.
Name given to this person at birth.
Other name used by this person.
Name used by this persion before marriage.
The date interval at which this name was valid.
The prefix or title used by the subject.
Additional term used following a person name.
The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.
The name by which the subject is officially registered.
The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.
Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.
Professional demographics details including name(s) , addresse(s) and telecommunication contact details.
The employment grade or position of the carer.
Team to which the individual belongs.
The period during which this professional was involved in care of the subject.
Personal name details of the individual.
Professional role details of the individual.
Organisation details to which the individual is attached.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Name in free text unstructured format.
Name previously used by this person.
Name given to this person at birth.
Other name used by this person.
Name used by this persion before marriage.
The date interval at which this name was valid.
The prefix or title used by the subject.
Additional term used following a person name.
The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.
The name by which the subject is officially registered.
The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.
Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.
Professional demographics details including name(s) , addresse(s) and telecommunication contact details.
The employment grade or position of the carer.
Team to which the individual belongs.
The period during which this professional was involved in care of the subject.
Personal name details of the individual.
Professional role details of the individual.
Organisation details to which the individual is attached.
Details about a contact person within organisation.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Name in free text unstructured format.
Name previously used by this person.
Name given to this person at birth.
Other name used by this person.
Name used by this persion before marriage.
The date interval at which this name was valid.
The prefix or title used by the subject.
Additional term used following a person name.
The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.
The name by which the subject is officially registered.
The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.
Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.
Details about a contact person within organisation.
The result, including findings and interpretation, of a laboratory investigation performed on specimens from individuals or related materials.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen.

A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. May be coded terminologies for example, LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', “Cortisol (am)” , "Potassium in perspiration" or "Liver Biopsy". The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example "Fasting blood glucose" or include other information, as "Potassium (PNA blood gas)".
Details of the laboratory which received the request and has overall responsibility to manage reporting of the test, even if other labs perform specific aspects.

The receiving laboratory may either perform the test or refer it to another laboratory. Where a different laboratory is responsible for performing the testing on specific analytes, we would expect those details to be carried in the laboratory analyte cluster via a slot. This slot is intended to carry details of the laboratory which received the request and has overall responsibility to manage reporting of the test, even if other labs perform specific aspects. For example CLUSTER.organization.
Details of additional clinicians or organisations who require a copy of the test result.
The 'Distribution list' is for information-only, and that the primary recipient of the report is the person intended to act on the information.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed.
Narrative description of the key findings.
For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.
Details about the physical substance that has been analysed.

If the specimen type is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test name, then this additional data is not required. Linking results to specific specimens may be recorded using 'Specimen identifier' elements in both the CLUSTER.specimen and the various results CLUSTER archetypes.
A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System to track the testing process.
This is some kind of tracking number/ID, not the name of the test, for example 'Full Blood count'.
The status of the laboratory test result as a whole.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
The date and/or time that the entire result was issued for the recorded ‘Test status’.

The 'diagnostic service' or 'lab discipline' that is responsible for the laboratory test result. This is intended to be a general categorisation and not to capture the organisational name of the laboratory.

For example anatomical pathology, immunology and transfusion medicine, medical microbiology, clinical pharmacology, medical genetics, medical biochemistry. Alternatively even more granular, such as hormones/endocrinology, haematology, autoantibodies, allergology. This assist clinicians in filtering between categories of results. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test result.

In most situations there is one test request and a single corresponding test result, however this repeating cluster allows for the situation where there may be multiple test requests reported using a single test result. As an example: 'a clinician asks for blood glucose in one request and Urea/electrolytes in a second request, but the lab analyser does both and the lab wishes to report these together'.
Results of the tests performed on the specimen.
This slot may carry an individual analyte, a group, panel or battery of multiple results, or a more complex and specific structure.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the laboratory test results.
For example: 'Severe hepatic impairment'. Coding of the diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.This diagnosis should be aligned with the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results.
This data element may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
Additional narrative about the test result not captured in other fields.
Name of the original laboratory test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
Structured details about the method of analysis, device or interpretation used.
This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation.
True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).
Issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result.

'Confounding factors' should be reserved for uncontrolled/unplanned issues of patient state/physiology that might affect interpretation for example 'recent exercise', 'day 1 of menstrual cycle'.
- Known or required pre-conditions, such as 'fasting' or 'day n of menstrual cycle' should be carried in the Cluster Specimen archetype 'Sampling conditions' element. In some cases pre-conditions are captured as part of the test name, for example 'Fasting blood glucose'.
- Known issues with specimen collection or handling should be carried in Cluster Specimen archetype 'Specimen quality' elements. For example 'prolonged use of tourniqet', 'sample haemolysed'.
Details of issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result. For example Last Normal Menstrual Period (LNMP).
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Digital image, video or diagram representing the test result.
Multiple formats are allowed but they should represent equivalent clinical content.
Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
A framework for the pathological classification and grading of malignancies using the TNM classification system.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The type of cancer being staged.
Coding of the type of the cancer with a terminology is strongly preferred.
The anatomical site where the assessed cancer is situated.
The anatomical subsite where the assessed cancer is situated.
Pathological assessment of the primary tumour.
Pathological assessment of the regional lymph nodes.
May include suffixes. For example: sentinel nodes (sn); isolated tumor cells (ITCs) (i+); and FNA or a core biopsy (f).
Pathological assessment of post-treatment residual tumour.
Pathological assessment of invasion into the lymphatic system.
Pathological assessment of invasion into the venous system.
Any other descriptor used in the pathological assessment.
Concatenation of pT, pN and pM categories plus any of G, R, L and V, if applicable.
Pathological staging is performed for a recurring cancer after a disease-free interval.
Pathological staging is performed during or following initial multimodality therapy.
Pathological staging is performed by postmortem examination after the death of the patient.
The edition of the TNM classification system used for the assessment.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Pathological assessment of invasion into nerve sheaths.
Presence of multiple primary tumours at a single site.
A suggestion, advice or proposal for clinical management.
May be coded, using a terminology, if required.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
A suggestion, advice or proposal for clinical management.
May be coded, using a terminology, if required.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Document to communicate information to others about the result of a test or assessment.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

items.items: *Document to communicate information to others about the result of a test or assessment.(en)
*Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.(en)
* e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.(en)
*Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.(en)
*The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.(en)
*Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.(en)
* e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.(en)
*The result, including findings and interpretation, of a laboratory investigation performed on specimens from individuals or related materials. (en)
*Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time. (en)
*Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen. (en)

A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. May be coded terminologies for example, LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', “Cortisol (am)” , "Potassium in perspiration" or "Liver Biopsy". The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example "Fasting blood glucose" or include other information, as "Potassium (PNA blood gas)".
*Details of the laboratory which received the request and has overall responsibility to manage reporting of the test, even if other labs perform specific aspects. (en)

The receiving laboratory may either perform the test or refer it to another laboratory. Where a different laboratory is responsible for performing the testing on specific analytes, we would expect those details to be carried in the laboratory analyte cluster via a slot. This slot is intended to carry details of the laboratory which received the request and has overall responsibility to manage reporting of the test, even if other labs perform specific aspects. For example CLUSTER.organization.
*Details of additional clinicians or organisations who require a copy of the test result. (en)
The 'Distribution list' is for information-only, and that the primary recipient of the report is the person intended to act on the information.
*This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified. (en)
*The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person. (en)
*The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed. (en)
For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'.
*The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system. (en)
Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
*The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS). (en)

Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.
*Details about the physical substance that has been analysed. (en)

If the specimen type is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test name, then this additional data is not required. Linking results to specific specimens may be recorded using 'Specimen identifier' elements in both the CLUSTER.specimen and the various results CLUSTER archetypes.
*A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System to track the testing process. (en)
This is some kind of tracking number/ID, not the name of the test, for example 'Full Blood count'.
*The status of the laboratory test result as a whole. (en)
*The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted'). (en)
*The date and/or time that ‘Overall test status’ was issued. (en)

*The 'diagnostic service' or 'lab discipline' that is responsible for the laboratory test result. This is intended to be a general categorisation and not to capture the organisational name of the laboratory. (en)

For example anatomical pathology, immunology and transfusion medicine, medical microbiology, clinical pharmacology, medical genetics, medical biochemistry. Alternatively even more granular, such as hormones/endocrinology, haematology, autoantibodies, allergology. This assist clinicians in filtering between categories of results. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
*Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test result. (en)

In most situations there is one test request and a single corresponding test result, however this repeating cluster allows for the situation where there may be multiple test requests reported using a single test result. As an example: 'a clinician asks for blood glucose in one request and Urea/electrolytes in a second request, but the lab analyser does both and the lab wishes to report these together'.
*Results of the tests performed on the specimen. (en)
This slot may carry an individual analyte, a group, panel or battery of multiple results, or a more complex and specific structure.
*Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the laboratory test results. (en)

For example: 'Severe hepatic impairment', 'Salmonella contamination'. Coding of the diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.This diagnosis should be aligned with the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.
*Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results. (en)
This data element may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
*Additional narrative about the test result not captured in other fields. (en)
*Name of the original laboratory test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed. (en)
*The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available. (en)
*Structured details about the method of analysis, device or interpretation used. (en)
*This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation. (en)
True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).
*Issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result. (en)

'Confounding factors' should be reserved for uncontrolled/unplanned issues of patient state/physiology that might affect interpretation for example 'recent exercise', 'day 1 of menstrual cycle'.
- Known or required pre-conditions, such as 'fasting' or 'day n of menstrual cycle' should be carried in the Cluster Specimen archetype 'Sampling conditions' element. In some cases pre-conditions are captured as part of the test name, for example 'Fasting blood glucose'.
- Known issues with specimen collection or handling should be carried in Cluster Specimen archetype 'Specimen quality' elements. For example 'prolonged use of tourniqet', 'sample haemolysed'.
*Details of issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result. For example Last Normal Menstrual Period (LNMP). (en)
*The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'. (en)
*The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
*Digital image, video or diagram representing the test result. (en)
Multiple formats are allowed but they should represent equivalent clinical content.
*Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Amended'. (en)
*Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'. (en)
*To record details of a laboratory specimen. (en)
*Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory. (en)
*Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples. (en)
*Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen. (en)
*The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy, resection. (en)
*Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken. (en)

e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
*The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken. (en)
*The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place. (en)
*Dimensions / weight / quantity of sample or other physical details of a bodily fluid. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles. (en)
*The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy. (en)
*The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory. (en)
*Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory. (en)
*An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen. (en)
*An error arose when handling the specimen. (en)
*The specimen was too old to analyse accurately. (en)
*An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory. (en)
*The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons. (en)
*The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting. (en)
*The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed. (en)
*The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed. (en)

*Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home. (en)

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result.
*The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation. (en)
*Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen. (en)
*The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen. (en)
*Additional detailed description of method of sample collection. (en)
*The total number of containers holding this specimen. (en)
*Addtional details related to specific collection methods e.g. needle biopsy. (en)
*A physical site on or within the human body.(en)
*Identification of a single physical site either on, or within, the human body.(en)

*This data element is the only mandated data point in this archetype and should be used as the primary data point to record an anatomical location with a commonly used name. It is strongly recommended that 'Body site name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. Use the other data elements for laterality, aspect, region and anatomical line to provide more detail.
This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available.
If body site name is already identified in the parent archetype, then this data element may be redundant. Alternatively, a use case has been identified where the value may be duplicated into this element to support semantic querying using this archetype, rather than the data element within the parent.(en)
*The side of the body on which the identified body site is located.(en)

*If the identified body site has no laterality, this data element should not have a value. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include laterality, then this data element is redundant.(en)
*Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support the 'Body site name'.(en)
*For example: adjacent to the vermilion border; a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.(en)
*Additional detail about the anatomical site using alternative approaches to describe the same body site.(en)
*For example, relative location or precise locations using coordinates. (en)
*Image or other media used to support identification of the body site.(en)
*Additional detail using theoretical lines drawn through anatomical structures used to provide a consistent reference point on the human body.(en)

*Common anatomical lines have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. The additional use of this data element allows for recording of the typical position of the heart's apex beat at 5th intercostal space, left side, and mid-clavicular line. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include anatomical line, then this data element is redundant.(en)
*Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the apex of the axilla.(en)
*Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the anterior axillary skinfold.(en)
*Line running vertically down the surface of the body, passing through the posterior axillary skinfold.(en)
*Line running vertically down the surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the midpoint of the clavicle.(en)
*Line running vertically down the face through the midpoint of the pupil when looking directly forward.(en)

*Line running vertically which divides the body into left and right portions, passing through the head, spinal cord, and umbilicus. Alternatively it can refer to a line dividing a body part into two equal portions, for example a digit.(en)
*Line running vertically down the posterior surface of the body, parallel to the midline and passing through the inferior point of the scapula.(en)
*Qualifying detail about the specific aspect of the identified body site.(en)

*Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. For example: proximal urethra; plantar aspect of the left thumb. Multiple aspects can also be described, if required, by allowing for 0..2 occurrences. For example: a lesion may be on the left anterior/lateral (ie anterolateral) chest wall. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the aspect, then this data element is redundant.(en)
*Additional detail using a specific region or a point on, or within, the identified body site.(en)

*Use to increase precision of identification of the body site, if required. For example, the upper right quadrant or McBurney's point on the abdominal wall or interphalangeal joint of the great toe. If the 'Body site name' data element uses pre-coordinated terms that include the specific site, then this data element is redundant.(en)
*Towards the midline of the body site.(en)
*Towards the side, or edge, of the body site.(en)
*Above the body site, often meaning towards the head.(en)
*Below the body site, often meaning towards the feet.(en)
*Towards the front, or ventral surface, of the body site.(en)
*Towards the back, or dorsal surface, of the body site.(en)
*More central or closer to the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.(en)
*More peripheral, or further from the point of attachment, and usually describing part of a limb, digit or appendage.(en)
*In the middle of the body site.(en)
*Towards the mouth. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.(en)
*Towards the anus. Usually used to describe locations within the digestive system.(en)
*Away from the surface of the body site.(en)
*Towards the surface of the body site.(en)
*Towards the back of the hand or top of the foot. To be used as opposites of palmar or plantar, not as a synonym of posterior.(en)
*Findings and interpretation of histopathology (anatomic pathology) tests performed on tissues and body fluids. (en)
*Findings recorded on examination of a gross specimen. (en)
*Details of an individual histopathology finding, often related to a specific anatomical location or specimen. (en)
*True if the tissue is available for examination. (en)
*Details of specimen(s) related to this examination. (en)
*A narrative description of the histopathology finding. (en)
*Single word, phrase of brief description representing the interpretation of the histopathology finding. A coded term is preferred. (en)
*A narrative description of the group of histopathology findings. (en)
*A group of findings within the histopathology examination. The Runtime name constraint allows identification of the type of histopathology examination performed. (en)
*Rich text or other multimedia representation of this particular result as issued by the diagnostic service. (en)
Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
*Details of specimen related to this finding. (en)
Squamous cell carcinoma NOS (not otherwise specified)
Low-grade neuroendocrine tumour - atypical carcinoid tumour
invasive tumour in more than 3 blocks
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) / cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 1 (CIN 1)
High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) / cervical intraepithelial lesion grade 2 (CIN 2)
High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) / cervical intraepithelial lesion grade 3 (CIN 3)
Suspicious for squamous intraepithelial lesion (PIL) / cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
*Details of tumour involvement at margins of surgical resections/biopsies. (en)
*Evidence of tumour at a surgical resection margin. (en)
*Details where tumour is present at the surgical resection margin. (en)
*When tumour is present at surgical resection margin, the maximal length of involvement. (en)
*Details where tumour is absent from surgical resection margins. (en)
*When tumour is absent, the distance from tumour to the closest surgical resection margin. (en)
*A text description of tumour involvement at the surgical resection margin. (en)
*Ttumour is present at the surgical resection margin. (en)
*Tumour is absent from the surgical resection margin. (en)
*Presence of tumour at surgical resection margins has not been determined. (en)
*Presence of tumour at the surgical resection margin is equivocal. (en)
*The name of the margin being described e.g. Deep margin, Vascular margin, Bronchial margin. (en)
*The location of the margin being described. (en)
*The nature of involvement of the tumour with the surgical margin. (en)
*Details of a specimen container. This is often integral to workflow and reporting of pathology specimens, particularly antamical and histological pathology specimens.(en)
*Identifier of the place from where the container should be collected.(en)
*The unique identifier given to the container. May be multiple.(en)
*The data and time that the specimen was uplifted for transportation to the laboratory.(en)
*Identifier of person or agency responsible for transporting the container to the lab.(en)
*Any special fixative or transport medium requirements.(en)

*Stage I is carcinoma strictly confined to the cervix; extension to the uterine corpus should be disregarded. The diagnosis of both Stages IA1 and IA2 should be based on microscopic examination of removed tissue, preferably a cone, which must include the entire lesion. (en)
*Invasive cancer identified only microscopically. Invasion is limited to measured stromal invasion with a maximum depth of 5 mm and no wider than 7 mm. (en)
*Measured invasion of the stroma no greater than 3 mm in depth and no wider than 7 mm diameter. (en)
*Measured invasion of stroma greater than 3 mm but no greater than 5 mm in depth and no wider than 7 mm in diameter. (en)
*Clinical lesions confined to the cervix or preclinical lesions greater than Stage IA. All gross lesions even with superficial invasion are Stage IB cancers. (en)
*Clinical lesions no greater than 4 cm in size. (en)
*Clinical lesions greater than 4 cm in size. (en)
*Stage II is carcinoma that extends beyond the cervix, but does not extend into the pelvic wall. The carcinoma involves the vagina, but not as far as the lower third. (en)
*No obvious parametrial involvement. Involvement of up to the upper two-thirds of the vagina. (en)
*Obvious parametrial involvement, but not into the pelvic sidewall. (en)

*Stage III is carcinoma that has extended into the pelvic sidewall. On rectal examination, there is no cancer-free space between the tumour and the pelvic sidewall. The tumour involves the lower third of the vagina. All cases with hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney are Stage III cancers. (en)
*No extension into the pelvic sidewall but involvement of the lower third of the vagina. (en)
*Extension into the pelvic sidewall or hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney. (en)
*Stage IV is carcinoma that has extended beyond the true pelvis or has clinically involved the mucosa of the bladder and/or rectum. (en)
*Spread of the tumour into adjacent pelvic organs. (en)
*To record findings of tumour metastases in lymph nodes. (en)
*Number of nodes which show tumour involvement. (en)
*Extent of tumour expressed as a maximum length. Applies only to an individual node. (en)
*The anatomical location of the lymph node or site being reported. (en)
*Nature or grade of the tumour, if present. (en)
*The tumour is of a focal nature. (en)
*The tumour is of a diffuse nature. (en)
*Extent of extranodal tumour expressed as a maximum length. (en)
*The node is completely invaded by tumour. (en)
*Findings of lymph node involvement with tumour. (en)
*Tumour is present in left sided nodes only. (en)
*Tumour is present in right side nodes only. (en)
*Tumour is present in nodes on both sides. (en)
*Tumour is absent from the lymph node site. (en)
*Lymph node involvement by tumour is equivocal. (en)
*Llymph node involvement by tumour has not been determined. (en)
*The nature of tumour has not been determnined. (en)
*Findings of extension of tumour beyond a node capsule. (en)
*Extra-capsular involvement by tumour has not been determined. (en)
*Findings related to extension of tumour external to the nodal capsule. (en)
*A text description of lymph node involvement by tumour. (en)
*The name for the lymph node site being reported. May be a general location e.g. 'Axillary nodes', a relative site e.g. 'Sentinel nodes' or a individual node. (en)
*Lymph node involvement with tumour is present. (en)
*Has the appropriate lymph node tissue been made available for examination? (en)
*Further details of lymph node metastasis at this site e.g individual nodes or further levels (en)
*The route by which the tumour became involved in lymph node tissue. (en)
*The tumour involved the lymph node by direct spread. (en)
*The tumour involved the lymph node by metastasis. (en)
*Findings of whether marker dye has been taken up by the lymph node or lymph node group. (en)
*Radioactivity count measured after use of radiocolloid. (en)
*To record the phycial properties of an object. (en)
*Narrative description of the physical properties of the object. (en)
*Digital image, video or diagram representing the findings. (en)
*The width or breadth of the object from side to side. (en)
*The vertical height or depth of the object. (en)
*The three dimensional volume of the object. (en)
*The two dimensional area of the object. (en)
*Details about a contact person within organisation. (en)
*Professional demographics details including name(s) , addresse(s) and telecommunication contact details. (en)
*The employment grade or position of the carer. (en)
*The period during which this professional was involved in care of the subject. (en)
*Organisation details to which the individual is attached. (en)
*Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party. (en)
*Name given to this person at birth. (en)
*Name used by this persion before marriage. (en)
*The date interval at which this name was valid. (en)
*The prefix or title used by the subject. (en)
*Additional term used following a person name. (en)
*The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes. (en)
*The name by which the subject is officially registered. (en)
*The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier. (en)
*Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified. (en)
*A framework for the pathological classification and grading of malignancies using the TNM classification system. (en)
*Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time. (en)
*Coding of the type of the cancer with a terminology is strongly preferred. (en)
*The anatomical site where the assessed cancer is situated. (en)
*The anatomical subsite where the assessed cancer is situated. (en)
*Pathological assessment of the regional lymph nodes. (en)
*May include suffixes. For example: sentinel nodes (sn); isolated tumor cells (ITCs) (i+); and FNA or a core biopsy (f). (en)
*Pathological assessment of invasion into the lymphatic system. (en)
*Pathological assessment of invasion into the venous system. (en)
*Any other descriptor used in the pathological assessment. (en)
*Concatenation of pT, pN and pM categories plus any of G, R, L and V, if applicable. (en)
*Pathological staging is performed for a recurring cancer after a disease-free interval. (en)
*Pathological staging is performed during or following initial multimodality therapy. (en)
*Pathological staging is performed by postmortem examination after the death of the patient. (en)
*The edition of the TNM classification system used for the assessment. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
*For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents. (en)
*Pathological assessment of invasion into nerve sheaths. (en)
*Presence of multiple primary tumours at a single site. (en)
*A framework for the classification and grading of malignancies using the TNM classification system. (en)
*Clinical TNM pre-treatment classification based on physical examination, imaging and biopsies. (en)
*Clinical assessment of the regional lymph nodes. (en)
*Pathological staging. Based on the clinical staging, results of procedures and pathological/histo-pathological assessment. (en)
*Pathological assessment of the regional lymph nodes. (en)
*The overall Clinical staging derived from each T, N and M component e.g T1aM0NX. May include additional TNM descriptors. (en)
*The overall Pathological staging derived from each pT, pN and pM component. May include additional TNM descriptors. (en)
*A text comment on the Clinical staging. (en)
*A text comment on the Pathological staging. (en)
*Presence of residual tumour cannot be assessed. (en)
*Presence of residual tumour cannot be assessed. (en)
*Details about an multimedia representation of the clinical data. (en)
*Multimedia representation of the clinical observation or finding. (en)
*Title or identification of the multimedia resource. (en)
*Date/time that the multimedia resource was created. (en)
*Date/time that the multimedia resource was published. (en)
*Name of the creator of the resource. (en)
*A suggestion, advice or proposal for clinical management. (en)
*May be coded, using a terminology, if required. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
*For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents. (en)
Histopatološki izvid je skladen s citopatološkim izvidom
A suggestion, advice or proposal for clinical management.
May be coded, using a terminology, if required.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
